page.title: 15Ecology of the Wolfords
page.content: The Topography is of undulating hills from 75-140 metres above sea level, with tree lined hedgerows around comparatively small fields. The Hedgerows are mainly hawthorn with oak and ash trees following the demise of the elm. Little Wolford Heath is the primary woodland being planted with conifers, sycamores, poplars, ash, oak and chestnut. The soil is mainly clay with some limestone brash mostly draining into Nethercote brook a deep slow flowing treelined water course. Here the inhabitants are principally water voles, herons, kingfishers, moorhens, trout and sticklebacks. The insects include mayfly and dragonfly. Mammals are fallow, roe and muntjack deer, foxes, badgers, hares, rabbits, grey squirrels,plus small rodents. Birds include game birds, Kestrels, Sparrow hawks and 3 sorts of owls.
